content.description: Squat start with left hand on a low incut edge and right hand on cool wide pinch at the best part (bottom) of the rail. Climb the overhang, probably using a bad left hand crimp, before gaining a decent three finger edge, after which its about V4. Top out as for Si's Highball + Tweaker. The movement is physical and punchy, with the 1st and 3rd moves being particularly hard. You'll wanna give that crimp some chalk and brushing love. Even though the holds are good, pulling on isn't necessarily a gimme. For those looking for an easier option, you get 8ish points if you start standing (lh bad crimp, rh rail)
content.location: This is in the corridor on the same boulder as Tweaker.

content.description: Sit start in compression, with the left hand on the flat rail/jug hold, right hand on your choice of edges under the roof. Make a hard slap with the left hand to a jug, before entering into an iron cross sequence and toping out on the left side of the boulder as for Si's Highball
content.location: On the big boulder, starts on the right side (facing uphill) next to the little cave.

content.description: Jump start to jugs and climb the slab of the big boulder. There are some shiny new bolts on top of this one for an unknown reason

Sit start with your left hand on a crimp under the roof, and your right hand on the incut crimp low on the arete. Climb the overhanging arete, probably using an aggressive right hand slap at the start. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J02R6UEFzMQ
content.location: The smaller boulder closest to the bridge.

content.description: Gem of a climb. Sit start on a blocky pinch on the left of the block. Awkwardly sit up and follow a lip traverse on the upward trending arete to a big move and a jug at 10 feet. Looks fine, but the movement sucks.
content.location: The leftmost boulder if you're facing uphill, on the side facing the river with the big overhang.

content.description: This is a very small roadside area about 20 minutes outside of Oakridge recently discovered by Adam Oliver. On a typical day you'll see a couple other parties fishing in the area. The boulders sit on the west shoulder of Hills Creek Lake a stones throw from the road. Most likely they fell off the craggy choss protuberance above and/or were blasted to the shore during road construction. Their position means that they get a lot of sun, and they're usually the first boulders in the Willamette Valley to dry in winter, needing only a couple hours of good weather to be climbable. The rock feels like some sort of basalt, so it's a little slicker than nearby areas like Fisher and Tumble, but that means the rock tends to form difficult lines. There's a bathroom across the bridge if you need it.Name was changed to avoid confusion with other zones...
